Max., Tac., Suet., or Plin.), <hi rend="ital">whenever</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">cum ad aliquod oppidum venerat, eadem lectica usque ad cubiculum deferebatur,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:5:11:section=27" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Verr. 2, 5, 11, § 27</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO">2, 1, 46, § 120</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">2, 3, 67, § 156</bibl>; 2, 4, 61, § 137; 2, 5, 10, § 27; <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> Fl. 7, 16</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">10, 21</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,011:2:26:68" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Agr. 2, 26, 68</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,040:32:113" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Or. 32, 113</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,039:24:93" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Brut. 24, 93</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">(Cassi vellaunus) cum equitatus noster se in agros ejecerat, essedarios ex silvis emittebat,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,001:5:19" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. G. 5, 19</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO">3, 14</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">3, 15</bibl>; 4, 7; 5, 35; 7, 22; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,002:1:58" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> B. C. 1, 58</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:J. 92:8" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Sall.</author> J. 92, 8</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:44:4" default="NO" valid="yes">44, 4</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">cum comminus venerant, gladiis a velitibus trucidabantur,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:38:21:12" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 38, 21, 12</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0588,001:Epam. 3:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Nep.</author> Epam. 3, 6</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1014,001:Ep. 11:4" default="NO"><author>Sen.</author> Ep. 11, 4</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0860,001:3:10:8" default="NO"><author>Curt.</author> 3, 10, 8</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0860,001:3:10:11" default="NO">3, 10, 11</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:7:1:4" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 7, 1, 4</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1254,001:15:22:5" default="NO"><author>Gell.</author> 15, 22, 5</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1254,001:17:18:3" default="NO">17, 18, 3</bibl>; Gai <bibl default="NO"><author>Inst.</author> 4, 15</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>Pacat.</author> 9</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n11873.61" n="(b)" level="5"> With principal predicate in <hi rend="ital">perf. indic.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">Pacuvius qui Syriam usu suam fecit, cum vino ... sibi parentaverat,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1014,001:Ep. 12:8" default="NO"><author>Sen.</author> Ep. 12, 8</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1014,001:108:14" default="NO">108, 14</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n11873.62" n="b" level="4"> With <hi rend="ital">pluperf. subj.</hi>, an <hi rend="ital">imperf. indic.</hi> in principal sentence: <cit><quote lang="la">cum fossam latam cubiculari lecto circumdedisset, ejusque transitum ... conjunxisset, eum ipse detorquebat,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:5:20:59" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Tusc. 5, 20, 59</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:3:41:section=94" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Verr. 2, 3, 41, § 94</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">cum cohortes ex acie procucurrissent, Numidae ... effugiebant, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,002:2:41" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. C. 2, 41</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">cum in jus duci debitorem vidissent, undique convolabant,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:2:27:8" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 2, 27, 8</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:25:3:11" default="NO" valid="yes">25, 3, 11</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:5:48:2" default="NO" valid="yes">5, 48, 2</bibl>.— </sense><sense id="n11873.63" n="4" level="3"> In anterior clauses with <hi rend="ital">imperf. subj.</hi> </sense><sense id="n11873.64" n="(a)" level="5"> When the principal clause expresses an immediate consequence ( = <hi rend="ital">pluperf. subj.</hi>): <cit><quote lang="la">Demaratus cum audiret dominationem Cypseli confirmari, defugit patriam ( = cum audivisset),</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,043:2:19:34" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Rep. 2, 19, 34</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,001:5:17" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. G. 5, 17</bibl> et saep.—</sense><sense id="n11873.65" n="(b)" level="5"> Where both verbs relate to one transaction, especially in remarks and replies: <cit><quote lang="la">(Epaminondas) cum gravi vulnere exanimari se videret, quaesivit salvusne esset clipeus, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,048:chapter=2" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Fin. 2</bibl></cit>, <cb n="CUM" /> 30, 97: <cit><quote lang="la">cum ex eo quaereretur quid esset dolus magnus, respondebat, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,055:chapter=3" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Off. 3</bibl></cit>. 14, 60; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,040:2:69:278" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Or. 2, 69, 278</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,002:25:70" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Rosc. Am. 25, 70</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:3:71:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 3, 71, 4</bibl> et saep.—</sense><sense id="n11873.66" n="(g)" level="5"> When the principal action takes place during the action of the dependent clause: <cit><quote lang="la">qui cum unum jam et alterum diem desideraretur, neque in eis locis inveniretur ... liberti Asuvii in eum invadunt, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,010:13:38" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Clu. 13, 38</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n11873.67" n="5" level="3"> For the <hi rend="ital">perf. indic.</hi> instead of <hi rend="ital">pluperf. subj.</hi> v. C. 1. d. infra.</sense><sense id="n11873.68" n="C" level="2"> In adverbial clauses of coincident time dependent on preterites ( = eo tempore quo), the clause with cum designating the time at which or during which the main action took place, <hi rend="ital">when, as, while</hi>.[The theory of the use of tenses and moods in these clauses is not fully settled. The older grammarians require the indicative if cum denotes pure time, but the subjunctive if denoting cause or relations similar to cause. Zumpt and others acknowledge that the rule is frequently not observed, attributing this to the predilection of the Latin language for the subjunctive. Recently Hoffmann (Zeitpartikeln der Lateinischen Sprache, 1st ed. 1860; 2d ed. 1873) and Lübbert (Syntax von Quom, 1870) have advanced the theory that cum requires the indicative if denoting absolute time, but the subjunctive if denoting relative time. They define absolute time as time co-ordinate or parallel with, or logically independent of, the time of the principal action, which performs the function of a chronological date for the principal action, and they consider it as a criterion that the clause might have constituted an independent sentence; while relative time is logically subordinate to the principal action. Hoffmann condenses his theory in the following words: cum with indicative names and describes the time at which the action of the principal sentence took place; cum with the subjunctive, on the contrary, designates the point of time at which, or the space of time during which, the action expressed in the principal sentence commenced or ended. The chief objections to this theory are: (1) Its vagueness.—(2) The facts that in many instances cum with the subjunctive clearly dates the main action (C. 3. a. <foreign lang="greek">b</foreign>, 2, and 4.; C. 3. a. 5.; C. 3. b. <foreign lang="greek">b</foreign>, 3. and 5.; C. 3. b. <foreign lang="greek">g</foreign> infra); that many of the subjunctive clauses with cum may be transformed into independent sentences (C. 3. b. <foreign lang="greek">b</foreign>, 2. and 3. infra); that many indicative clauses with cum are logically subordinate to the main action (C. 3. a. <foreign lang="greek">a</foreign>, 2. infra), and that when both moods are used in two co-ordinated clauses with cum belonging to the same main sentence, Hoffmann must account for the difference of the moods by explanations not drawn from his theory (<bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,011:2:64:64" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Agr. 2, 64, 64</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,010:30:83" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Clu. 30, 83</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,053:1:43:97" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Div. 1, 43, 97</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,048:2:19:61" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Fin. 2, 19, 61</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,037:67:272" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> de Or. 67, 272</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,002:2:17" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. C. 2, 17</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:6:40:17" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 6, 40, 17</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:30:44:10" default="NO" valid="yes">30, 44, 10</bibl>).—(3) The impossibility of clearly drawing the line between logical co-ordination and subordination; and the fact that, wherever it is drawn, there will be many passages not accounted for (cf. 1. <hi rend="ital">init.</hi> and many passages under C. 3. a. <foreign lang="greek">a</foreign>, 3.; C. 3. a. <foreign lang="greek">d</foreign>; C. 3. b. <foreign lang="greek">g</foreign>, etc.).—(4) That the supposed use of cum with the imperfect indicative is inconsistent with the received doctrine that the imperfect always designates a time relative to another time—a difficulty not satisfactorily met by Hoffman's assumption of an aoristic imperfect.]GENERAL RULE.—The predicate after cum is in the perfect indicative (or historical present) if the action is conceived as a point of time coincident with the time of the main action. It is either in the imperfect indicative or in the imperfect subjunctive if the action is conceived as occupying a period of time within which the main action took place (e. g.: <cit><quote lang="la">quid enim meus frater ab arte adjuvari potuit, cum ... furem se videre respondit? Quid in omni oratione Crassus ... cum pro Cn. Plancio diceret?</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,037:2:54:220" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> de Or. 2, 54, 220</bibl></cit>; <cit><quote lang="la">where dicebat might stand for diceret, but not responderet for respondit: cum ad tribum Polliam ventum est, et praeco cunctaretur, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:29:37:8" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 29, 37, 8</bibl></cit>; cf.: <cit><quote lang="la">cum tecum Ephesi collocutus sum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:13:55:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Fam. 13, 55, 1</bibl></cit>; and: <cit><quote lang="la">cum te Puteolis prosequerer,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 3, 10, 8</bibl></cit>: cum primum lex coepta ferri est, Liv 3, 14, 4; and: cum <pb n="492" /> <cb n="CUM" /> ferretur lex, <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> 5, 30, 4</bibl>; <cit><quote lang="la">also,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:4:3:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Fam. 4, 3, 1</bibl></cit>, and <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:3:58:7" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 3, 58, 7</bibl>). </sense><sense id="n11873.69" n="1" level="3"> Both predicates in the <hi rend="ital">perf. indic.</hi> (or <hi rend="ital">histor. pres.</hi>), both clauses denoting points of time (the principal predicate may be in any verbal form implying a perfect). </sense><sense id="n11873.70" n="a" level="4"> The clause expressing a momentary action: <cit><quote lang="la">posticulum hoc recepit quom aedis vendidit, Flaut. Trin. 1, 2, 157: scilicet qui dudum tecum venit cum pallam mihi Detulisti,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:Men. 2:3:46" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Men. 2, 3, 46</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:prol. 62" default="NO" valid="yes">prol. 62</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:Poen. 4:2:82" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Poen. 4, 2, 82</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:Ep. 2:2:33" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Ep. 2, 2, 33</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,005:4:1:57" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Hec. 4, 1, 57</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,002:2:3:21" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Heaut. 2, 3, 21</bibl> et saep.: <cit><quote lang="la">non tum cum emisti fundum Tusculanum, in leporario apri fuerunt,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0684,001:R. R. 3:3:8" default="NO"><author>Varr.</author> R. R. 3, 3, 8</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">in judiciis quanta vis esset didicit cum est absolutus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0803,005:Fragm. 4" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Tog. Cand. Fragm. 4</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">per tuas statuas vero cum dixit, vehementer risimus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,037:2:59:242" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> de Or. 2, 59, 242</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">cum occiditur Sex. Roscius, (servi) ibidem fuerunt,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,002:41:120" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Rosc. Am. 41, 120</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:2:29:section=70" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Verr. 2, 2, 29, § 70</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">1, 4, 11</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">2, 2, 66, § 160</bibl>; 2, 3, 47, § 112; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,008:29:85" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Caecin. 29, 85</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,022:55:157" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Sest. 55, 157</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,035:2:9:21" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Phil. 2, 9, 21</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,043:6:22:24" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Rep. 6, 22, 24</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:9:15:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Fam. 9, 15, 2</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:2:1:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Att. 2, 1, 5</bibl> et saep.: <cit><quote lang="la">tunc flesse decuit cum adempta sunt nobis arma,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:3:55:10" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 3, 55, 10</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:10:6:8" default="NO" valid="yes">10, 6, 8</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:28:42:14" default="NO" valid="yes">28, 42, 14</bibl>; 42, 46, 1; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1056,001:2:8:12" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vitr.</author> 2, 8, 12</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1056,001:2:1:7" default="NO" valid="yes">2, 1, 7</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1056,001:2:9:15" default="NO" valid="yes">2, 9, 15</bibl>; <cit><quote lang="la">6, 7, 4: semel dumtaxat vultum mutavit, tunc cum ... anulum in profundum dejecit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1038,001:6:9:6" default="NO"><author>Val. Max.</author> 6, 9, 6</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1038,001:8:8" default="NO">8, 8</bibl>, ext. 1; 9, 1, ext. 1; <cit><quote lang="la">9, 8, 1: rerum natura ... cum visum est deinde, (filium tuum) repetiit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1014,001:Cons. Polyb. 10:4" default="NO"><author>Sen.</author> Cons. Polyb. 10, 4</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1014,001:11:2" default="NO">11, 2</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1014,001:Q. N. 1:11:3" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Q. N. 1, 11, 3</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1014,001:6:25:4" default="NO">6, 25, 4</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">accepimus et serpentem latrasse cum pulsus est regno Tarquinius,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:8:153" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 8, 41, 63, § 153</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:2:90" default="NO" valid="yes">2, 24, 22, § 90</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:2:139" default="NO" valid="yes">2, 52, 53, § 139</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=cl.:21" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Claud. 21</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,004:2:3:61" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> S. 2, 3, 61</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,008:5:11:8" default="NO"><author>Ov.</author> Tr. 5, 11, 8</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0660,001:3:5:18" default="NO"><author>Tib.</author> 3, 5, 18</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1294,001:5:49:9" default="NO"><author>Mart.</author> 5, 49, 9</bibl>.—So, cum primum, <hi rend="ital">when first, the first time that, as soon as</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">jube vinum dari: jam dudum factum'st quom primum bibi,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,002:5:2:40" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> As. 5, 2, 40</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,006:prol. 17" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Cas. prol. 17</bibl>; Ter. Hec. alt. prol. 31; <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> And. prol. 1</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> Eun. 3, 3, 4</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">Pompeius cum primum contionem habuit ... ostendit, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:15:45" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Verr. 1, 15, 45</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:2:9:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Fam. 2, 9, 1</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:3:55:10" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 3, 55, 10</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:25:6:2" default="NO" valid="yes">25, 6, 2</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:25:29:4" default="NO" valid="yes">25, 29, 4</bibl>; 31, 3, 1; 40, 8, 1; 42, 34, 3; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0860,001:6:11:23" default="NO"><author>Curt.</author> 6, 11, 23</bibl>; but with <hi rend="ital">imperf. subj.</hi> when referring to a per. of time: <cit><quote lang="la">ipse cum primum pabuli copia esse inciperet, ad exercitum venit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,001:2:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. G. 2, 2</bibl></cit>.—In the poets and later writers, the <hi rend="ital">imperf. subj.</hi> often occurs where classic prose has the <hi rend="ital">perf. indic.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">effice ut idem status sit cum exigis qui fuit cum promitterem,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1014,001:Ben. 4:39:4" default="NO"><author>Sen.</author> Ben. 4, 39, 4</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">tum lacrimare debueras cum equo calcaria subderes,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0860,001:7:2:6" default="NO"><author>Curt.</author> 7, 2, 6</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=cl.:6" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Claud. 6</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,009:4:12:28" default="NO"><author>Ov.</author> P. 4, 12, 28</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n11873.71" n="b" level="4"> If the clause denotes a state, condition, or action of longer duration, it takes the <hi rend="ital">perf. indic.</hi> if asserted as a complete fact without regard to what happened during its progress (virtual point of time): <cit><quote lang="la">in quem Juppiter se convertit cum exportavit per mare ... Europen,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0684,001:R. R. 2:5:5" default="NO"><author>Varr.</author> R. R. 2, 5, 5</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ne cum in Siciliā quidem (bellum) fuit ... pars ejus belli in Italiam ulla pervasit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:5:2:section=6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Verr. 2, 5, 2, § 6</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">nempe eo (lituo) Romulus regiones direxit tum cum urbem condidit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,053:1:17:30" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Div. 1, 17, 30</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:3:54:section=125" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Verr. 2, 3, 54, § 125</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,033:7:20" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Lig. 7, 20</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,043:3:32:44" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Rep. 3, 32, 44</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">non tibi, cum in conspectu Roma fuit, succurrit? etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:2:40:7" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 2, 40, 7</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:34:3:7" default="NO" valid="yes">34, 3, 7</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0588,001:Iphicr. 2:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Nep.</author> Iphicr. 2, 4</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0588,001:Pelop. 4:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Pelop. 4, 3</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n11873.72" n="c" level="4"> With <hi rend="ital">perf. indic., by the time when, before</hi>, referring to facts which actually occurred before the action of the principal sentence: <cit><quote lang="la">ab Anaximandro moniti Lacedaemonii sunt ut urbem ... linquerent, quod terrae motus instaret, tum cum ... urbs tota corruit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,053:1:50:112" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Div. 1, 50, 112</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:22:36:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 22, 36, 4</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:34:31:15" default="NO" valid="yes">34, 31, 15</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1224,001:2:32" default="NO"><author>Prop.</author> 2, 32</bibl> (3, 30), 53.—</sense><sense id="n11873.73" n="d" level="4"> With <hi rend="ital">perf. indic.</hi> when actions in immediate sequence are represented as coincident: <cit><quote lang="la">ad quem cum accessimus, Appio, subridens, Recipis nos, inquit, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0684,001:R. R. 3:2:2" default="NO"><author>Varr.</author> R. R. 3, 2, 2</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">me primus dolor percussit, Cotta cum est expulsus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,039:89:303" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Brut. 89, 303</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">itaque ne tum quidem cum classem perdidisti, Mamertinis navem imperare ausus es,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:5:23:section=59" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Verr. 2, 5, 23, § 59</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">haec cum facta sunt in concilio, magna spe et laetitia omnium discessum est,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,002:3:87" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. C. 3, 87</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">cum Thessalos in armis esse nuntiatum est, Ap. Claudium ... senatus misit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:42:5:8" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 42, 5, 8</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Gracchus cum ex Sardiniā rediit, orationem ad populum habuit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1254,001:15:12:1" default="NO"><author>Gell.</author> 15, 12, 1</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,009:1:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Imp. Pomp. 1, 2</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,034:6:17" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Deiot. 6, 17</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,042:16:61" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Top. 16, 61</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,053:1:43:98" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Div. 1, 43, 98</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:5:21:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Fam. 5, 21, 2</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:4:44:10" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 4, 44, 10</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:4:60:8" default="NO" valid="yes">4, 60, 8</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:9:25:2" default="NO" valid="yes">9, 25, 2</bibl>; 22, 14, 12; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0588,014:11:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Nep.</author> Dat. 11, 1</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=jul.:31" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Caes. 31</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1254,001:1:23:5" default="NO"><author>Gell.</author> 1, 23, 5</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1224,001:3:20:37" default="NO"><author>Prop.</author> 3, 20, 37</bibl> (4, 21, 7).—Hence a <hi rend="ital">perf. indic.</hi> in co-ordination with <hi rend="ital">pluperf. subj.</hi>: cum sol nocte visus<cb n="CUM" />  esset ... et cum caelum discessisse visum est (decemviri ad libros ire jussi sunt), <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,053:1:43:97" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Div. 1, 43, 97</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n11873.74" n="2" level="3"> With a <hi rend="ital">perf. indic.</hi> (or <hi rend="ital">histor. pres.</hi>), the principal predicate in <hi rend="ital">imperf.</hi> </sense><sense id="n11873.75" n="a" level="4"> The action falling within the time of the principal predicate: <cit><quote lang="la">set Stalagmus quojus erat tunc nationis, quom hinc abit?</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,005:4:2:107" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Capt. 4, 2, 107</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,017:3:6:9" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Rud. 3, 6, 9</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,003:2:3:51" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Eun. 2, 3, 51</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">haec Crassi oratio cum edita est, quattuor et triginta tum habebat annos, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,039:43:161" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Brut. 43, 161</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">eo cum venio, praetor quiescebat,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:4:14:section=32" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Verr. 2, 4, 14, § 32</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO">2, 5, 69, § 178</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> Fl. 13, 20</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,027:1:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Pis. 1, 2</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,033:1:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Lig. 1, 3</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,035:2:21:52" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Phil. 2, 21, 52</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">3, 4, 11</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:13:35:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Fam. 13, 35, 2</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:6:1:13" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Att. 6, 1, 13</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">cum Caesari in Galliam venit, alterius factionis principes erant Aedui, alterius Sequani,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,001:6:12" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. G. 6, 12</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:J. 71:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Sall.</author> J. 71, 1</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">cum haec accepta clades est, jam C. Horatius et T. Menenius consules erant,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:2:51:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 2, 51, 1</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:21:39:4" default="NO" valid="yes">21, 39, 4</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:23:49:5" default="NO" valid="yes">23, 49, 5</bibl>; 28, 27, 14; 34, 16, 6; <cit><quote lang="la">45, 39, 1: merito me non adgnoscis, nam cum hoc factum est, integer eram,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1014,001:Ben. 5:24:3" default="NO"><author>Sen.</author> Ben. 5, 24, 3</bibl></cit>.—Post-class. writers generally use <hi rend="ital">imperf. subj.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">beneficium ei videberis dedisse cui tunc inimicissimus eras cum dares?</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1014,001:Ben. 5:19:7" default="NO"><author>Sen.</author> Ben. 5, 19, 7</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">bona quoque, quae tunc habuit cum damnaretur, publicabuntur,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:28:18:section=1" default="NO"><author>Dig.</author> 28, 18, § 1</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">pauper Fabricius (erat) Pyrrhi cum sperneret aurum,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Claud.</author> IV. Cons. Hon. 413</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n11873.76" n="b" level="4"> The action strictly anterior to the principal sentence, rare (1. d.): nam quod conabar cum interventum'st dicere, nunc expedibo, Pac. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Non.</author> p. 505, 3</bibl> (Trag. Rel. v. 65 Rib.): <cit><quote lang="la">cum est ad nos adlatum de temeritate eorum, etc., cetera mihi facillima videbantur ... multaque mihi veniebant in mentem, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:3:10:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Fam. 3, 10, 1</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:C. 51:32" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Sall.</author> C. 51, 32</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:6:515" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 6, 515</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,001:3:14" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> E. 3, 14</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n11873.77" n="3" level="3"> The predicate after cum conceived as a period or space of time (including repeated action) is either in the <hi rend="ital">imperf. indic.</hi> or <hi rend="ital">imperf. subj.</hi> [In ante-classical writers and Cicero the <hi rend="ital">imperf. indic.</hi> very frequent, and largely prevailing over the <hi rend="ital">subj.</hi>, except that when the principal predicate denotes a point of time (with <hi rend="ital">perf.</hi>), Cicero commonly uses the <hi rend="ital">subj.;</hi> the <hi rend="ital">imperf. indic.</hi> occurs in Cicero 241 times; in Caesar once with the force of a relativeclause (B. G. 1, 40, 5), and 3 times of repeated action; in Nep. once of repeated action (<bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0400,001:9:6" default="NO"><author>Att.</author> 9, 6</bibl>); in Sall. twice (J. 31, 20; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0400,001:H. 1:48:6" default="NO"><author>id.</author> H. 1, 48, 6</bibl> Dietsch); in <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:22" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 22</bibl> times; in <bibl default="NO"><author>Verg.</author> 4</bibl> times; in Ovid twice; in Tib. twice; in <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1224,001:3" default="NO"><author>Prop.</author> 3</bibl> times; in Val. Max. twice; then it disappears (except once each in Tac. and Mart.), but reappears in Gaius (3 times), Gellius (twice), and the Gallic panegyrists (several times)]. </sense><sense id="n11873.78" n="a" level="4"> Both predicates denoting spaces of time, the principal predicate always in the <hi rend="ital">imperf. indic.</hi> unless the mood is changed by other influences. </sense><sense id="n11873.79" n="(a)" level="5"> Cum with the <hi rend="ital">imperf. indic.</hi> (1) In express or implied opposition to other periods of time, esp. with tum or tunc: <cit><quote lang="la">eademne erat haec disciplina tibi quom tu adulescens eras?</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,004:3:3:17" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Bacch. 3, 3, 17</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">alium esse censes nunc me atque olim quom dabam?</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,001:3:3:13" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> And. 3, 3, 13</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,005:2:1:50" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Capt. 2, 1, 50</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,013:1:3:64" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Most. 1, 3, 64</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,012:2:2:26" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Mil. 2, 2, 26</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,001:1:1:69" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> And. 1, 1, 69</bibl>; Enn. ap. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,039:19:76" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Brut. 19, 76</bibl> (Ann. v. 222 Vahl.): <cit><quote lang="la">qui cum plures erant, paucis nobis exaequari non poterant, hi postquam pauciores sunt, etc.,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Auct. Her.</author> 4, 18, 25</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">qui (Pompeius) cum omnes Caesarem metuebamus ipse eum diligebat, postquam ille metuere coepit, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:8:1:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Att. 8, 1, 4</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">res per eosdem creditores per quos cum tu aderas agebatur,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:1:1:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Fam. 1, 1, 1</bibl></cit> (cf.: <cit><quote lang="la">Senatus consultum factum est de ambitu in Afranii sententiam quam ego dixeram cum tu adesses,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,058:2:9:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Q. Fr. 2, 9, 3</bibl></cit>): <cit><quote lang="la">Trebellium valde jam diligit: oderat tum cum ille tabulis novis adversabatur,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,035:6:4:11" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Phil. 6, 4, 11</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">non tam id sentiebam cum fruebar, quam tunc cum carebam,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,018:1:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Red. Quir. 1, 3</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">etenim tunc esset hoc animadvertendum cum classis Syracusis proficiebatur,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:5:43:section=111" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Verr. 2, 5, 43, § 111</bibl></cit> (so 111 times in Cicero, including the instances where the principal predicate is in the <hi rend="ital">perf.</hi>): <cit><quote lang="la">cum captivis redemptio negabatur, nos vulgo homines laudabant, nunc deteriore condicione sumus, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:25:6:14" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 25, 6, 14</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:10:7:2" default="NO" valid="yes">10, 7, 2</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:33:34:3" default="NO" valid="yes">33, 34, 3</bibl>; 34, 4, 10; 44, 36, 8; 45, 38, 1; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,009:2:6:9" default="NO"><author>Ov.</author> P. 2, 6, 9</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:13:473" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> M. 13, 473</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1038,001:6:3:1" default="NO"><author>Val. Max.</author> 6, 3, 1</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1038,001:4:1:10" default="NO">4, 1, 10</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1294,001:12:70:10" default="NO"><author>Mart.</author> 12, 70, 10</bibl>; Gai <bibl default="NO"><author>Inst.</author> 1, 184</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>Eum.</author> Grat. Act. 6</bibl>; cf.: cur eum, cum in consilium iretur, Cluentius et Canutius abesse patiebantur? Cur cum in <cb n="CUM" /> consilium mittebant, Stajenum judicem qui pecuniam dederant, non requirebant? <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,010:30:83" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Clu. 30, 83</bibl> (cum iretur, of the time when the judges retired; cum mittebant, of the previous time, when the parties were asked about the closing of the case; opp. cum iretur).—Poets, even in the class. per., sometimes use the <hi rend="ital">subj.</hi> in dependence upon the <hi rend="ital">indic.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">hic subito quantus cum viveret esse solebat, Exit humo,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:13:441" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 13, 441</bibl></cit>. —(2) The principal predicate denoting a mental act or reflection occasioned by, or accompanying the action of the clause with cum (mostly ante-class. and in Cicero): <cit><quote lang="la">desipiebam mentis cum illa scripta mittebam tibi,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,009:1:2:35" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Ep. 1, 2, 35</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,003:2:2:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Aul. 2, 2, 1</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,016:1:5:86" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Ps. 1, 5, 86</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">sed tu cum et tuos amicos in provinciam quasi in praedam invitabas, et cum eis praedabare, et ... non statuebas tibi rationem esse reddendam?</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:2:11:section=29" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Verr. 2, 2, 11, § 29</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">illas res tantas cum gerebam, non mihi mors, non exsilium ob oculos versabatur?</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,022:21:47" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Sest. 21, 47</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,013:3:1:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Cat. 3, 1, 3</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">3, 7, 16</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:2:10:section=26" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Verr. 2, 2, 10, § 26</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">2, 2, 13, § 33</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">2, 2, 35, § 86</bibl>; 2, 3, 86, § 198; 2, 5, 21, § 54; <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> Fl. 1, 1</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,034:1:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Deiot. 1, 3</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">8, 23</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,027:24:56" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Pis. 24, 56</bibl> and 57; <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> Ac. 2, 28, 89</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,040:13:41" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Or. 13, 41</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:2:15:43" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Tusc. 2, 15, 43</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:7:9:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Fam. 7, 9, 5</bibl> (22 times); <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:H. 1:48:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Sall.</author> H. 1, 48, 6</bibl> Dietsch (cf.: <cit><quote lang="la">num P. Decius cum se devoveret, et equo admisso in mediam aciem Latinorum inruebat, aliquid ... cogitabat?</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,048:2:19:61" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Fin. 2, 19, 61</bibl></cit>; cum se devoveret explains the circumstances of inruebat; hence acc. to 3. a. <foreign lang="greek">b</foreign>, 2. in <hi rend="ital">subj.;</hi> cf. Madv. ad loc., who reads devoverat).—(3) If the predicate after <hi rend="ital">cum</hi> has a meaning peculiar to the <hi rend="ital">imperf. indic.</hi>, which by the use of the <hi rend="ital">subj.</hi> would be effaced: quod erat os tuum, cum videbas eos homines, quorum ex bonis istum anulus aureus donabas? (descriptive <hi rend="ital">imperf.</hi>) <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:3:80:section=187" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Verr. 2, 3, 80, § 187</bibl>; so, <cit><quote lang="la">fulgentis gladios hostium videbant Decii, cum in aciem eorum inruebant,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:2:24:59" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Tusc. 2, 24, 59</bibl></cit>: cum de plebe consulem non accipiebat ( = accipere nolebat, conative <hi rend="ital">imperf.</hi>), <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,039:14:55" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Brut. 14, 55</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">cum vim quae esset in sensibus explicabamus, etc.,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> Ac. 2, 12, 37</bibl></cit> (the verbum dicendi refers to a certain stage in the discourse, for which Cicero uses the <hi rend="ital">imperf. indic.</hi> in independent sentences, e. g. N. D. 3, 29, 71; 3, 6, 15; de Or. 1, 53, 230; 2, 19, 83; 2, 84, 341); so, <cit><quote lang="la">equidem ... risum vix tenebam, cum Attico Lysiae Catonem nostrum comparabas,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,039:8:293" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Brut. 8, 293</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">cum censebam,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,037:1:62:264" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> de Or. 1, 62, 264</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">cum dicebam,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:6:1:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Fam. 6, 1, 5</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">cum ponebas,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,048:2:19:63" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Fin. 2, 19, 63</bibl></cit>; so esp. in Cicero's letters the phrase cum haec scribebam = <hi rend="ital">while I am writing this</hi>, to preserve the meaning of an epistolary tense, referring to a state, condition, or action in progress at the time of writing the letter: <cit><quote lang="la">res, cum haec scribebam, erat in extremum adducta discrimen,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:12:6:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Fam. 12, 6, 2</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO">3, 12, 2</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">5, 12, 2</bibl>; 6, 4, 1; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:5:20:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Att. 5, 20, 5</bibl> et saep.; cum haec scriberem, scripsissem, scripsi, are not epistolary tenses, but refer to events happening after the letter or part of it was finished, = <hi rend="ital">when I wrote, had written</hi>, <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 2, 15, 3</bibl>; 10, 4, 7; 4, 10, 2; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,058:3:1:6:section=19" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Q. Fr. 3, 1, 6, § 19</bibl>; Cael. ap. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:8:6:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Fam. 8, 6, 5</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">8, 13, 2</bibl>; <cit><quote lang="la">sometimes cum dabam = cum scribebam,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:12:16:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Fam. 12, 16, 3</bibl></cit> (but cf.: <cit><quote lang="la">cum scriberem, as epistolary tense, in oblique discourse,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:15:13:7" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Att. 15, 13, 7</bibl></cit>).—(4) The coincidence in time of two actions is made emphatic, = eo ipso tempore quo: <cit><quote lang="la">tum cum insula Delos ... nihil timebat, non modo provinciis sed etiam Appiā viā jam carebamus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,009:18:55" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Imp. Pomp. 18, 55</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,035:1:15:36" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Phil. 1, 15, 36</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">13, 8, 17</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,015:10:31" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Sull. 10, 31</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:2:8:20" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Tusc. 2, 8, 20</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,055:3:27:100" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Off. 3, 27, 100</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,020:45:118" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Dom. 45, 118</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n11873.80" n="(b)" level="5"> The predicate after cum is in the <hi rend="ital">imperf. subj.</hi> (1) To impart to the clause a causal, adversative or concessive meaning besides the temporal relation: <cit><quote lang="la">antea cum equester ordo judicaret, improbi magistratus in provinciis inserviebant publicanis (a logical consequence),</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:3:41:section=94" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Verr. 2, 3, 41, § 94</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">sed cum jam honores (Hortensii) et illa senior auctoritas gravius quiddam requireret, remanebat idem (dicendi genus) nec decebat idem,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,039:95:327" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Brut. 95, 327</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,035:1:1:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Phil. 1, 1, 1</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,002:15:42" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Rosc. Am. 15, 42</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">16, 45</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,027:10:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Pis. 10, 2</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:25:13:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 25, 13, 1</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:26:5:1" default="NO" valid="yes">26, 5, 1</bibl>.—(2) To indicate circumstances under which the main action took place, and by which it is explained: <cit><quote lang="la">Flaminius, cum tripudio auspicaretur, pullarius diem differebat, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,053:1:35:77" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Div. 1, 35, 77</bibl></cit>: <pb n="493" /> <cb n="CUM" /> equidem cum peterem magistratum, solebam in prensando dimittere a me Scaevolam, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,037:1:24:112" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> de Or. 1, 24, 112</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,036:2:17:52" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Inv. 2, 17, 52</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:41:1:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 41, 1, 2</bibl> (cf. 3. b. <foreign lang="greek">b</foreign>, 3.).—(3) To describe the locality of the main action: quom essem in provinciā legatus, quam plures ad praetores et consules vinum honorarium dabant, Cato ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Isid.</author> Orig. 20, 3, 8</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">Zenonem cum Athenis essem audiebam frequenter,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,050:1:21:59" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> N. D. 1, 21, 59</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO">1, 28, 79</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:2:14:34" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Tusc. 2, 14, 34</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:3:8:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Fam. 3, 8, 5</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:2:11:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Att. 2, 11, 1</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">12, 5, 4</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">16, 14, 1</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:4:12:section=29" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Verr. 2, 4, 12, § 29</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:5:54:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 5, 54, 3</bibl> (cf. 3. b. <foreign lang="greek">b</foreign>, 4.).—(4) To designate the time of the main action as a condition: <cit><quote lang="la">cum ageremus vitae supremum diem, scribebamus hoc,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,048:4:27:54" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Fin. 4, 27, 54</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">cum jam in exitu annus esset, Q. Marcius ... magistratu abiturus erat,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:39:23:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 39, 23, 1</bibl></cit> (cf. 3. b. <foreign lang="greek">b</foreign>, 5.).—</sense><sense id="n11873.81" n="(g)" level="5"> If both the clause with cum and the principal predicate denote repeated action, the predicate with cum in class. prose is in the <hi rend="ital">imperf. indic.</hi> or <hi rend="ital">subj.</hi> according to the rules under <foreign lang="greek">a</foreign> and <foreign lang="greek">b</foreign>; the principal predicate being always in the <hi rend="ital">imperf. indic.;</hi> but in ante-class. writers cum has always the <hi rend="ital">imperf. indic.</hi> (1) <hi rend="ital">Imperf. indic.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">tum mi aedes quoque arridebant, quom ad te veniebam, tuae,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,002:1:3:55" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> As. 1, 3, 55</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,001:1:1:45" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Am. 1, 1, 45</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,017:4:7:25" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Rud. 4, 7, 25</bibl> sqq.; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,003:2:3:19" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Eun. 2, 3, 19</bibl>; Cinc. de Re Mil. ap. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1254,001:16:4:5" default="NO"><author>Gell.</author> 16, 4, 5</bibl>; Asell. ap. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1254,001:2:13:4" default="NO"><author>Gell.</author> 2, 13, 4</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:2:7:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Att. 2, 7, 4</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:2:13:section=34" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Verr. 2, 2, 13, § 34</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,002:1:79:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. C. 1, 79, 2</bibl>; Gai <bibl default="NO"><author>Inst.</author> 2, 101</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>Pacat.</author> Pan. 9 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">cum a nostro Catone laudabar vel reprehendi me a ceteris facile patiebar,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,040:13:41" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Or. 13, 41</bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0588,025:9:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Nep.</author> Att. 9, 6</bibl>.—To distinguish from adversative relations, as <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,003:3:9" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Rosc. Com. 3, 9</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:12:39:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Att. 12, 39, 2</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,037:1:14:62" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> de Or. 1, 14, 62</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,002:3:44:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. C. 3, 44, 6</bibl>; Gai <bibl default="NO"><author>Inst.</author> 2, 254</bibl>.—If only the clause with cum, but not the principal predicate, denotes repeated action, the latter is in the <hi rend="ital">perf.</hi>, the former in <hi rend="ital">imperf. indic.</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,002:2:17" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. C. 2, 17</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,016:5:10" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Arch. 5, 10</bibl>.—(2) <hi rend="ital">Imperf. subj.</hi>, mostly denoting circumstances to explain the main action: cum dilectus antiquitus fieret ... tribunus militaris adigebat, etc., Cinc. de Re Mil. ap. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1254,001:16:4:2" default="NO"><author>Gell.</author> 16, 4, 2</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">Hortensius cum partiretur tecum causas, prorogandi locum semper tibi relinquebat,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,039:51:190" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Brut. 51, 190</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,053:1:45:102" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Div. 1, 45, 102</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,037:1:54:232" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> de Or. 1, 54, 232</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,039:62:222" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Brut. 62, 222</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:3:66:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 3, 66, 2</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:5:25:12" default="NO" valid="yes">5, 25, 12</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">ex hoc effectos panes, cum in colloquiis Pompeiani famem nostris objectarent, vulgo in eos jaciebant (causal),</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,002:3:48" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. C. 3, 48</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,048:2:19:62" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Fin. 2, 19, 62</bibl>; so, <cit><quote lang="la">according to class. usage,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1014,001:Ep. 86:11" default="NO"><author>Sen.</author> Ep. 86, 11</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0860,001:5:2:7" default="NO"><author>Curt.</author> 5, 2, 7</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0860,001:6:5:18" default="NO">6, 5, 18</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0860,001:7:3:13" default="NO">7, 3, 13</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=jul.:65" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Caes. 65</bibl>; <cit><quote lang="la">contrary to class. usage,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1038,001:3:6:6" default="NO"><author>Val. Max.</author> 3, 6, 6</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1014,001:Ep. 30:7" default="NO"><author>Sen.</author> Ep. 30, 7</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1014,001:77:8" default="NO">77, 8</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,004:2:91" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> H. 2, 91</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>Spart.</author> Had. 18</bibl>. —</sense><sense id="n11873.82" n="(d)" level="5"> In other instances (which are rare), both moods occur, either without any discrimination, or for special reasons. (1) Ante-class.: <cit><quote lang="la">nam quom modo exibat foras, ad portum se aibat ire,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,017:2:2:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Rud. 2, 2, 2</bibl></cit>. —(2) Class.: <cit><quote lang="la">ut, cum L. Opimii causam defendebat, C. Carbo nihil de Gracchi nece negabat, sed id jure factum esse dicebat,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,037:2:25:106" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> de Or. 2, 25, 106</bibl></cit> (cf.: <cit><quote lang="la">nuper cum ego C. Sergii Oratae ... causam defenderem, nonne omnis nostra in jure versata defensio est?</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 1, 39, 178</bibl></cit>; in each of these sentences the clause with <hi rend="ital">cum</hi> sustains exactly the same relation to the principal predicate; but the former has the <hi rend="ital">imperf.</hi> in the principal sentence, and in this connection Cic. prefers the <hi rend="ital">indic.</hi> after cum): <cit><quote lang="la">similiter arbitror ... illum (oratorem) de toto illo genere non plus quaesiturum esse, quid dicat, quam Polycletum illum, cum Herculem fingebat, quem ad modum pellem aut hydram fingeret (fingebat, for euphony, in view of the foll. fingeret),</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,037:2:16:70" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> de Or. 2, 16, 70</bibl></cit>; cf.: <cit><quote lang="la">nec vero ille artifex cum faceret Jovis formam ... contemplabatur aliquem, e quo similitudinem duceret,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,040:2:9" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Or. 2, 9</bibl></cit>.—Without assignable reason: <cit><quote lang="la">casu, cum legerem tuas litteras, Hirtius erat apud me,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:15:1:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Att. 15, 1, 2</bibl></cit>; cf.: <cit><quote lang="la">Hasdrubal tum forte cum haec gerebantur, apud Syphacem erat,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:29:31:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 29, 31, 1</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">cum haec Romae agebantur, Chalcide Antiochus ipse sollicitabat civitatium animos, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:36:5:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 36, 5, 1</bibl></cit>; cf.: <cit><quote lang="la">cum haec in Hispaniā gererentur, comitiorum jam appetebat dies,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:35:8:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 35, 8, 1</bibl></cit> (Weissenb. gerebantur): <cit><quote lang="la">cum haec agebantur, Chalcide erat Antiochus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:36:15:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 36, 15, 1</bibl></cit>; cf.: <cit><quote lang="la">cum haec agerentur jam consul viā Labicanā ad fanum Quietis erat,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:4:41:8" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 4, 41, 8</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:35:2:1" default="NO" valid="yes">35, 2, 1</bibl>.—(3) PostAug. writers almost always use <hi rend="ital">imperf. subj.</hi>, disregarding the class. usage: ipsa <cb n="CUM" /> fruebatur arte cum pingeret (cf. <foreign lang="greek">a</foreign>, 2.), <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1014,001:Ep. 9:7" default="NO"><author>Sen.</author> Ep. 9, 7</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1014,001:Cons. Marc. 23:3" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Cons. Marc. 23, 3</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1318,002:34" default="NO"><author>Plin.</author> Pan. 34</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">tunc erat mendacio locus cum ignota essent externa ... nunc vero, etc. (opposition of times),</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1014,001:Q. N. 4:2:24" default="NO"><author>Sen.</author> Q. N. 4, 2, 24</bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1014,001:Ep. 97:9" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Ep. 97, 9</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1294,001:2:61:1" default="NO"><author>Mart.</author> 2, 61, 1</bibl>; cf. Don. ad <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,001:3:3:13" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> And. 3, 3, 13</bibl> (3. a. <foreign lang="greek">a</foreign>, 1. supra): <cit><quote lang="la">cum haec proderem habebant et Caesares juvenes sturnum, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:10:120" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 10, 41, 59, § 120</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n11873.83" n="b" level="4"> If the principal predicate denotes a point of time, and the predicate with cum a period of time, the former is in the <hi rend="ital">perf. indic.</hi> unless changed by construction; the latter </sense><sense id="n11873.84" n="(a)" level="5"> In the <hi rend="ital">imperf. indic.</hi>, according to the rules a. <foreign lang="greek">a</foreign>, except 2. (1) When the time of the cum clause is opposed to other periods of time: <cit><quote lang="la">res quom animam agebat tum esse offusam oportuit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,019:4:3:85" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Trin. 4, 3, 85</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,020:4:2:20" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Truc. 4, 2, 20</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,009:3:3:50" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Ep. 3, 3, 50</bibl> (3, 4, 21); <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,013:5:1:68" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Most. 5, 1, 68</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">quod cum res agebatur nemo in me dixit, id tot annis post tu es inventus qui diceres?</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,035:2:9:22" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Phil. 2, 9, 22</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,043:2:23:43" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Rep. 2, 23, 43</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,053:1:41:92" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Div. 1, 41, 92</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">1, 45, 101</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> Ac. 2, 28, 90</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> Quint. 19, 60</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">17, 54</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">19, 61</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:3:90:section=210" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Verr. 2, 3, 90, § 210</bibl> et saep.; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:22:60:25" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 22, 60, 25</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:4:597" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 4, 597</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0660,001:1:10:8" default="NO"><author>Tib.</author> 1, 10, 8</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0660,001:1:10:19" default="NO">1, 10, 19</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1224,001:2:1:31" default="NO"><author>Prop.</author> 2, 1, 31</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1224,001:5" default="NO">5</bibl> (4), 10, 24.—The <hi rend="ital">subj.</hi> may be used if the principal action is represented as a consequence or result: <cit><quote lang="la">o, Astaphium, haut isto modo solita's me ante appellare, Sed blande, quom illuc quod aput vos nunc est, aput me haberem,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,020:1:2:60" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Truc. 1, 2, 60</bibl></cit> (Lübbert conjectures habebam); <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,055:2:1:2" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Off. 2, 1, 2</bibl> and 3; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,048:4:27:54" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Fin. 4, 27, 54</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,002:4:11" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Rosc. Am. 4, 11</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:3:57:section=130" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Verr. 2, 3, 57, § 130</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,014:3:8" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Mur. 3, 8</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:5:53:9" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 5, 53, 9</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:10:6:9" default="NO" valid="yes">10, 6, 9</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:43:21:1" default="NO" valid="yes">43, 21, 1</bibl>; <cit><quote lang="la">44, 39, 7.— Hence the mood may change in co-ordinate clauses: tum, cum haberet haec res publica Luscinos, Calatinos, etc., homines ... patientiā paupertatis ornatos, et tum, cum erant Catones, Phili, etc., tamen hujusce modi res commissa nemini est (haberet, concessive),</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,011:2:24:64" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Agr. 2, 24, 64</bibl></cit>.—(2) To make emphatic the coincidence of time, = eo ipso tempore (a. <foreign lang="greek">a</foreign>, 4.): <cit><quote lang="la">cum is triumphus de Liguribus agebatur, Ligures ... coloniam ipsam ceperunt,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:41:14:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 41, 14, 1</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,022:26:56" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Sest. 26, 56</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,035:2:36:90" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Phil. 2, 36, 90</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,053:2:1:3" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Div. 2, 1, 3</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:5:37:section=97" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Verr. 2, 5, 37, § 97</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:1:4:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Att. 1, 4, 1</bibl>.—(3) To preserve the peculiar force of the <hi rend="ital">imperf. indic.</hi> (a. <foreign lang="greek">a</foreign>, 3.): cum iste jam decedebat, ejus modi litteras ad eos misit, etc. (conative <hi rend="ital">imperf.</hi>), <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:2:70:section=172" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Verr. 2, 2, 70, § 172</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">cum Africanus censor tribu movebat centurionem ... inquit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,037:2:67:272" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> de Or. 2, 67, 272</bibl></cit> (cf.: <cit><quote lang="la">cum (censor) M. Antistio equum ademisset,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 2, 71, 287</bibl></cit>).—</sense><sense id="n11873.85" n="(b)" level="5"> With the <hi rend="ital">imperf. subj.</hi> (1) Always when cum means <hi rend="ital">while</hi> (time during which): quomque caput caderet, carmen tuba sola peregit et, etc., Enn. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Lact.</author> ad Stat. Th. 11, 56</bibl> (Ann. v. 508 Vahl.): <cit><quote lang="la">magistratus quom ibi adesset, occepta'st agi,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,003:prol. 22" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Eun. prol. 22</bibl></cit> (Lübbert conjectures adsedit); Enn. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Macr.</author> S. 6, 1</bibl> (Ann. v. 106 Vahl.): <cit><quote lang="la">Alexandrum uxor sua, cum simul cubaret, occidit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,036:2:49:144" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Inv. 2, 49, 144</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">armati, cum sui utrosque adhortarentur ... in medium inter duas acies procedunt,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:1:25:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 1, 25, 1</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0684,001:R. R. 2:81" default="NO"><author>Varr.</author> R. R. 2, 81</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>Auct. Her.</author> 4, 52, 65</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,039:3:10" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Brut. 3, 10</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,010:62:175" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Clu. 62, 175</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,001:2:19" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. G. 2, 19</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,002:3:57" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> B. C. 3, 57</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:1:30:8" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 1, 30, 8</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:10:30:3" default="NO" valid="yes">10, 30, 3</bibl> et saep.—(2) To connect a logical (causal, etc.) relation with the temporal meaning (a. <foreign lang="greek">b</foreign>, 1.): <cit><quote lang="la">cum ille Romuli senatus ... temptaret ut ipse gereret sine rege rem publicam, populus id non tulit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,043:2:12:23" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Rep. 2, 12, 23</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">an pater familiarissimis suis succensuit cum Sullam et defenderent et laudarent? (causal),</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,015:17:49" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Sull. 17, 49</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">tum cum bello sociorum tota Italia arderet, homo non acerrimus ... C. Norbanus in summo otio fuit (concessive),</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:5:4:section=8" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Verr. 2, 5, 4, § 8</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">quibus rebus cum unus in civitate maxime floreret, incidit in eandem invidiam, etc. (adversative),</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0588,005:3:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Nep.</author> Cim. 3, 1</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">sed cum jam appropinquantium forma lemborum haud dubia esset ... tunc injecta trepidatio est,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:44:28:10" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 44, 28, 10</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:3:90:section=211" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Verr. 2, 3, 90, § 211</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,010:31:84" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Clu. 31, 84</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,014:3:8" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Mur. 3, 8</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,035:3:2:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Phil. 3, 2, 3</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:1:2:4" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Tusc. 1, 2, 4</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>Auct. Her.</author> 4, 24, 33</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,002:2:7" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. C. 2, 7</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:25:9:10" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 25, 9, 10</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:21:41:12" default="NO" valid="yes">21, 41, 12</bibl>.—(3) To explain the main fact by circumstances: <cit><quote lang="la">quem quidem hercle ego, in exilium quom iret, redduxi domum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,011:5:4:19" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Merc. 5, 4, 19</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">consule me, cum esset designatus tribunus, obtulit in discrimen vitam suam,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,022:28:61" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Sest. 28, 61</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">haec epistula est, quam nos, in aedibus Apronii cum litteras conquireremus, invenimus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:3:66:section=154" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Verr. 2, 3, 66, § 154</bibl></cit>: Socrates, cum XXX. tyranni essent, pedem portā <cb n="CUM" /> non extulit, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:8:2:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Att. 8, 2, 4</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">Brundusii cum loquerer cum Phaniā, veni in eum sermonem ut dicerem, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:3:5:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Fam. 3, 5, 3</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">itaque, cum populum in curias triginta divideret, nomina earum (Sabinarum) curiis imposuit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:1:13:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 1, 13, 6</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Ap. Claudius, ovans cum in urbem iniret, decem milia pondo argenti, etc., in aerarium tulit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:41:28:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 41, 28, 6</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,010:20:55" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Clu. 20, 55</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,035:12:8:20" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Phil. 12, 8, 20</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,029:chapter=47" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Scaur. 47</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,036:2:31:96" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Inv. 2, 31, 96</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:2:22:53" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Tusc. 2, 22, 53</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,053:1:52:119" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Div. 1, 52, 119</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,055:2:8:27" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Off. 2, 8, 27</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,040:2:55:225 sq" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Or. 2, 55, 225 sq.</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:1:9:13" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Fam. 1, 9, 13</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">6, 6, 5</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:1:39:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 1, 39, 4</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:3:63:6" default="NO" valid="yes">3, 63, 6</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:4:53:11" default="NO" valid="yes">4, 53, 11</bibl> et saep.—(4) To describe the place of the main action (a. <foreign lang="greek">a</foreign>, 3.): <cit><quote lang="la">cum essem in castris ad fluvium Pyramum, redditae mihi sunt uno tempore a te epistulae duae,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:3:11:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Fam. 3, 11, 1</bibl></cit>; <cit><quote lang="la">so with cum essem (essemus, etc.),</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 2, 19, 1</bibl></cit>; 3, 4, 1; 13, 56, 1; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:1:10:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Att. 1, 10, 1</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">14, 19, 1</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> Ac. 1, 1, 1</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,043:1:39:61" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Rep. 1, 39, 61</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0684,001:R. R. 3:13" default="NO"><author>Varr.</author> R. R. 3, 13</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,001:4:11" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. G. 4, 11</bibl> et saep.: <cit><quote lang="la">Eumenes rex ab Romā cum in regnum rediret ... mactatus est ( = on the journey),</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:42:40:8" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 42, 40, 8</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Agesilaus cum ex Aegypto reverteretur ... in morbum implicitus decessit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0588,001:Ages. 8:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Nep.</author> Ages. 8, 6</bibl></cit>.—The <hi rend="ital">perf. indic.</hi> (cum fui, etc.) refers to temporary visits to a place: <cit><quote lang="la">Gallo narravi, cum proxime Romae fui, quid audissem,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:13:49:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Att. 13, 49, 2</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">proxime cum in patriā meā fui, venit ad me, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1318,001:4:13:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> Ep. 4, 13, 3</bibl></cit>.—(5) To designate the time by natural occurrences (a. <foreign lang="greek">a</foreign>, 4.): <cit><quote lang="la">ipsi comprehensi a me, cum jam dilucesceret, deducuntur,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,013:3:3:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Cat. 3, 3, 6</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">cum advesperasceret, cum lucesceret,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:15:4:8" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Fam. 15, 4, 8</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">cum lux appropinquaret,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,006:9:21" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Tull. 9, 21</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">cum dies instaret,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,036:2:31:96" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Inv. 2, 31, 96</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">cum comitiorum tempus adpeteret,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:28:10:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 28, 10, 1</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">cum dies comitiorum adpropinquaret,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:3:34:7" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 3, 34, 7</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:10:13:2" default="NO" valid="yes">10, 13, 2</bibl>.—But when a date is given as a point of time, the <hi rend="ital">perf. indic.</hi> is used: <cit><quote lang="la">cum ea dies venit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:4:44:10" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 4, 44, 10</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:6:20:4" default="NO" valid="yes">6, 20, 4</bibl>.—(6) When the action of the cum clause is interrupted or ended by the main action: <cit><quote lang="la">cum hanc jam epistulam complicarem, tabellarii a vobis venerunt, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,058:3:1:5:section=17" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Q. Fr. 3, 1, 5, § 17</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">L. Octavius, cum multas jam causas diceret, adulescens est mortuus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,039:68:241" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Brut. 68, 241</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">cum plures jam tribus dicto esse audientem pontifici duumvirum juberent ... ultimum de caelo quod comitia turbaret intervenit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:40:42:10" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 40, 42, 10</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">cum maxime conquereretur apud patres ... repente strepitus ante curiam ... auditur,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:8:33:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 8, 33, 4</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">haec cum maxime dissereret, intervenit Tarquinius,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:1:50:7" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 1, 50, 7</bibl></cit>; <cit><quote lang="la">so with cum maxime,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:1:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Fam. 1, 5</bibl></cit>, a, 2; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:23:24:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 23, 24, 6</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:30:33:12" default="NO" valid="yes">30, 33, 12</bibl>.—(7) If the clause with cum has the force of a participial adjunct of the principal predicate (cum diceret = dicens, or dicendo): <cit><quote lang="la">Caesarem saepe accusavit, cum adfirmaret illum numquam, dum haec natio viveret, sine curā futurum ( = adfirmans, or adfirmando),</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,022:63:132" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Sest. 63, 132</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Antigonus in proelio, cum adversus Seleucum dimicaret, occisus est ( = dimicans),</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0588,021:3:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Nep.</author> Reg. 3, 2</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">impulit ut cuperem habere, cum diceret,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0684,001:R. R. 3:2:8" default="NO"><author>Varr.</author> R. R. 3, 2, 8</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,058:2:9" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Q. Fr. 2, 9</bibl> (11), 3; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,010:42:119" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Clu. 42, 119</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">56, 153</bibl>; id. pro Corn. Maj. Fragm. 16; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,031:5:12" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Mil. 5, 12</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,037:1:57:243" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> de Or. 1, 57, 243</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,040:37:129" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Or. 37, 129</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,048:1:5:16" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Fin. 1, 5, 16</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,036:2:34:105" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Inv. 2, 34, 105</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1038,001:1:2" default="NO"><author>Val. Max.</author> 1, 2</bibl>, ext. 1; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,009:1:9:42" default="NO"><author>Ov.</author> P. 1, 9, 42</bibl>.—(8) In the historians, in a summary reference to events already related: <cit><quote lang="la">cum haec in Achaiā atque apud Dyrrhachium gererentur ... Caesar mittit, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,002:3:57" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. C. 3, 57</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">cum civitas in opere ac labore adsiduo reficiendae urbis teneretur, interim Q. Fabio ... dicta dies est,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:6:1:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 6, 1, 6</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">cum hic status in Boeotiā esset, Perseus ... misit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:42:56:10" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 42, 56, 10</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:33:36:1" default="NO" valid="yes">33, 36, 1</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:34:22:3" default="NO" valid="yes">34, 22, 3</bibl>; 38, 8, 1; 42, 64, 1; 45, 11, 1.— </sense><sense id="n11873.86" n="(g)" level="5"> In all other cases the <hi rend="ital">imperf. subj.</hi> is regularly used in class. prose, even if the action of the clause with cum is logically independent of the principal sentence: <cit><quote lang="la">illum saepe audivi, hic, cum ego judicare jam aliquid possem, abfuit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,039:71:248" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Brut. 71, 248</bibl></cit>: senatus consultum est factum de ambitu in Afranii sententiam, in quam ego dixeram, cum tu adesses. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,058:2:7" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Q. Fr. 2, 7</bibl> (9), 3; so always (class.) with cum maxime, <hi rend="ital">precisely when, just when</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">cum maxime haec in senatu agerentur, Canuleius ... (ad populum) ita disseruit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:4:3:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 4, 3, 1</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">cum maxime Capua circumvallaretur, Syracusarum oppugnatio ad finem venit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:25:23:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 25, 23, 1</bibl></cit>.—In a very few instances the <hi rend="ital">imperf. indic.</hi> occurs without apparent reason: an vero cum honos agebatur familiae vestrae ... succensuit<pb n="494" /> <cb n="CUM" />  pater tuus cum Sullam defenderent (probably to distinguish the two cum clauses), <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,015:17:49" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Sull. 17, 49</bibl> (cf.: <cit><quote lang="la">cum jus amicitiae, societatis, adfinitatis ageretur, cum, etc., eo tempore tu non modo non ... retulisti, sed ne ipse quidem, etc.,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> Quint. 16, 53</bibl></cit>): <cit><quote lang="la">ille versus, qui in te erat collatus cum aedilitatem petebas,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,058:1:3:8" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Q. Fr. 1, 3, 8</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">cum ex oppido exportabatur (Dianae statua) quem conventum mulierum factum esse arbitramini? ... Quid hoc totā Siciliā est clarius quam omnes convenisse cum Diana exportaretur ex oppido? etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:4:35:section=77" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Verr. 2, 4, 35, § 77</bibl></cit>.—Poets and post-class. writers frequently disregard the class. usage, the former by using either mood instead of the other, the latter by the un-Ciceronian use of the <hi rend="ital">subj.;</hi> v. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1224,001:2:9:15" default="NO"><author>Prop.</author> 2, 9, 15</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1224,001:5" default="NO">5</bibl> (4), 4, 10; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0660,001:1:10:16" default="NO"><author>Tib.</author> 1, 10, 16</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:7:148" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 7, 148</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">12, 735</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1294,001:13:122" default="NO"><author>Mart.</author> 13, 122</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0860,001:8:12:16" default="NO"><author>Curt.</author> 8, 12, 16</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0860,001:9:2:24" default="NO">9, 2, 24</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:11:1:89" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 11, 1, 89</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:36:46" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 36, 6, 5, § 46</bibl>;
